marklogic.body:
I'm not sure I loved the book as much as you did, but it was certainly thought-provoking! I loved the same characters you did - with Alec being, by far my favorite, with Taylor a close second. And wasn't Mrs. Pettigrew just the most horrid person?
I did enjoy the humor and the writing, but it wasn't a "wow" read for me. Dame Lettie's end was a huge shock! For such a humorous, little book - that was dark and unexpected.
1. That was the most interesting thing to me - and I think you're right that the author was showing how each character thought of death in their own way. I found it interesting that only two of the characters (Mortimer and Taylor) were willing to pursue the thought that the voice was death itself - and they both seemed to have come to a healthy understanding of their own impending demise.
2. Olive was an odd character. I thought it was hilarious how, at Godfrey's age, simply a glimpse of stocking and garter was enough to get him going. :) I think in some ways, she represented the youth they were all trying to hold onto - especially for the older man she married.
3. I also have a complicated relationship with thoughts of my own death. On the one hand, as a Christian, I don't worry about what will happen to ME after death. But as a wife and a mother, the thought of dying young and leaving my husband and children behind is terrifying to me - to the point that I have often struggled with real panic and Anxiety any time I have a health issue. I also think that in the church grief is often belittled or minimized. It is too easy to murmur platitudes like, "She's in a better place," or "You will see him again" and then forget that the person is suffering from very real, heart-breaking, often debilitating grief over their loss right NOW.
Thanks for hosting, Amy - while I didn't love the book, I am definitely Glad for having read it, and look forward to our next discussion.
